title: How many total Model 3 and Model Y vehicles will Tesla deliver to customers in 2020?
preds: The company delivered 88,400 vehicles in the first quarter, including 76,200 Model 3’s and Y’s and 12,200 Model S’s and X’s.

Source thedriven.io
260927+22755+52294+10602+ little bump gets you to 350,000
Quarter 4 tends to be the highest quarter for sales, and with on 119,139 to go, it is likely that they will reach the goal.

I think based on q2 and q3 results it's a safe bet that they will deliver more than 400,000. https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q2-2020-vehicle-production-deliveries
https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q3-2020-vehicle-production-deliveries

FYI - Musk continues to project good sales for year

Tesla has begun exporting China-made Model 3s to Europe. The Giga Shanghai-made electric vehicles will be sold in more than ten European countries, including Germany, Italy, Switzerland and France, said Tesla China VP Grace Tao (Para. 1). Thousands of Model 3s are in Shanghai Port and are due to be shipped next Tuesday. Manufacturing Model 3 in China has a number of important advantages that will allow Tesla to develop rapidly: \
Reference
\
Fox, E. (2020). Tesla Giga Shanghai Has Thousands of Model 3 Ready to Export to 10+ of European Countries Next Week. Tesmanian. October 19, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-giga-shanghai-made-model-3-sr-to-export-to-tens-european-countries-says-china-vp
The crowd moved to "More than 400,000" after Q3 deliveries were announced.  I think the crowd has this one right.

I expect Tesla to deliver ~ 440,000 Model 3 & Y vehicles in 2020.  This is due to expecting another 20-30% increase of the two vehicles in Q4 over Q3.  With their China Gigafactory coming into production and the front and rear being a single stamped piece, I believe that they will increase their numbers.  A decrease from Q3 would be the only way they don't hit 400,000 deliveries, which I view as extremely unlikely.  I almost never make such a strong prediction, but this is a case that I must make that prediction.  I am assuming that California continues to keep a grip on the COVID spread and prevents shutdown.  Also, I don't expect Model Y to be produced in China until 2021.  I think Musk is still shooting for 500k total vehicle deliveries in 2020, so that would put the 3 & Y prediction around 450k for the year.

I get 280,587 3Q =124,044 +2Q =80,277 +1Q =76266
Q1 and Q2 numbers retrieved from
Q2 2020 Update

Still thinking 4Q will be over 130,000, i
Still believe they can reach 400k in 2020, but I'll hedge that bet somewhat.
124k delivered in Q3 bringing total to 280k. 120k needed to break 400k in Q4, which is below Q3. New factories ramp-up and probably no Covid production shutdown point in right direction.

https://cleantechnica.com/2020/09/16/tesla-vehicle-deliveries-from-2016-to-2020-charts-graphs/
Tesla did deliver 280k model 3/Y until 3Q20. So to reach each milestone they would need to deliver:
350k - 70k
400k - 120k
If Q4 = Q3, then slightly more than 400,00.

I tend to get ahead of myself.  Overconfidence in the most likely outcome often causes me to overlook other possibilities.  [@SE_Meyer captured some of those in his last prediction.]  So I'll back off from my all-in forecast.  I'm still much more optimistic than the crowd. As a side note, I wonder if the same forecasters of this question are also following the question on the TSLA stock price.  The crowd is bullish on TSLA stock.  Yet for this question it doesn't seem to believe that delivery numbers will be good.  There is definitely some cognitive dissonance going on, unless the Tesla fans are watching the price question, and the naysayers the other.

At 204,150 w/ an average of 68,050 /Q
So we can expect 272,200-328,250 for 2020 at this rate. (Tesla's target is 378,067) Now we just need to watch the news. https://ir.tesla.com/press-release/tesla-q2-2020-vehicle-production-deliveries
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/tesla-delivered-139300-vehicles-in-q3-2020-10-02
https://cleantechnica.com/2020/09/03/tesla-delivery-estimate-q3-2020-140000-q4-2020-194000/

A surprise indeed.
Together with the approx. 157,300 of Q1/Q2, they're now at 281,400 model 3 + Ys for three quarter(s) of 2020.
A conservative estimate would give them at least 95,000 more units in Q4 (285,000 divided by 3), over-weighting the third quarter in order to extract a trend (which also E. Musk gave in his guidance
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1140996 )
shows that a) it may well be another 120,000+ quarter, and b) any delivery more than 118,600 in Q4 resolves the question on bin 5. I see two caveats:
/ If China does not play out as planned and Tesla will experience any sort of retaliation measures against their Shanghai plant (supply chain, production, tariffs, non-tariff trade obstacles,...) for the U.S. trade politics against China's CP, the promises will likely not be kept.
/ The danger of no-brainer precautions to a flawless product, that Tesla Inc. does NOT take beforehand, is not yet gone completely: in 2017, it was a products recall of 123,000 model S globally due to low-grade rusty screws in the steering assistance that caused upheaval. If this repeats, on a now even larger scale, Tesla Inc. will not be first and foremost building new cars for delivery, but repair and upgrade 500,000+ of its old models for safety reasons. Trying to blend this into a forecast, I'll leave some weight on lower figures. Bin 3, however can be ruled out almost surely, since it meant less than 70,000 units in Q4.
Why hold back, more Octobottles are coming.

Tesla delivered 124,100 Model 3/Y vehicles in Q3.  If they can match that number in Q4 they will beat the 400k number.  Either I'm missing something, always a possibility, or the crowd is asleep.  If I'm in the weeds here please set me straight. https://electrek.co/2020/10/02/tesla-tsla-q3-record-delivery-electric-cars/
Hedging until the Q3 numbers are out.

The crowd thinks, with 100% certainty, that Tesla will sell between 300,000 and 400,000 Model 3 and Model Y cars in 2020.  But the crowd also thinks, with 97% certainty, that Tesla stock will end the year at over $400 per share. Can both of these be true?  Can Tesla sell fewer cars than Elon Musk himself has forecast, but the stock does not correct to the downside.  I don't know what the TSLA stock price will be, but I'll overweight sales surprise to the upside vis a vis the crowd.  Q3 deliveries should be announced soon, so we'll see.

Bloomberg 9/23 "Tesla has said it anticipates delivering 500,000 vehicles in 2020, up about 36% from 2019. " This is the optomistic view, reality may be less forgiving. And these are not all Model 3&Y. Running changes in Y and 3 may  make for more effeciency, but could also cost time & units near term. Single piece front and rear will speed things up once solidly in production.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-09-22/tesla-bear-says-battery-day-all-smoke-and-mirrors-video Some critical questions Tesla likely won't answer... "The new guidance from Musk implies deliveries of between 477,750 and 514,500 cars, a range that encompasses the company’s previously stated goal to deliver half a million cars in 2020."
The number of deliveries of model S/X which are reported together, is 22,800 units (12,200 as of Q1 + 10,600 as of Q22020) so 50k units seem to be very viable.
Even if the deliver 60k model S/X the demand for which appears to be decreasing in 2020, they still have to produce (ready for delivery) and deliver 417,750 units min., due to a lack of other models available or ready for production, which means 130,750 units per each of Q3 and Q4 (on average).
If you believe in "Battery day's" business and delivery projection, bin 5 is your bin.
I don't think this will happen. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/22/elon-musk-at-battery-day-tesla-deliveries-to-rise-30percent-to-40percent-in-2020.html

Just hedging a bit & awaiting the Q3 figures due maybe by 20 October.
Hope everyone will be not too disappointed, if it is 85k vehicles of these models or less...

Diverging from the crowd, biasing towards higher numbers.
More EV's could be better for the planet and simplify the auto industry and push the envelope on AV's technology.

Tesla reported Model 3 and Y sales for Q2 at 80,050 units, and 76,200 for Q1. Historically, there is a 20-30 seasonally higher uptake for the 2nd half of the year, and the quarterly growth trend of 8%, so without accounting for Covid-19, we would be looking at something like 380,000 units. There is not enough data to establish how Q2 was good "despite Corona" or there are other effects at play, but I think that the consensus is about right with the possibility of being too conservative.

Correction, they won't be building themselves until 2021. Off by one. 
"Smart Delivery" won't be an option until 2022 - you order online and the car travels to your driveway after your payment clears. ( In some geos it will even go thru the local car wash before it shows up. )
Why not? By Q4 these things will be building themselves and then driving themselves to the customer's house.

Together with Q2 deliveries of 80,050 Model 3 + Ys, there should be a cumulative deliveries of about 157,316 vehicles of these types year to 30 June 2020.
Honestly, I don't see how they would manage to increase quarterly deliveries by roughly one third for Q3 and Q4 to reach the fourth bin, even though they stick to their forecast of 500,000 deliveries for the time being (50k of which then will be Models S and X and, haha, cybertrucks). E. Musk has not yet been reportedly seen walking on water. It seems he is more interested in big talk to make his second of twelve step option pay plan pay out (condition: 6 consecutive months of market value for Tesla Inc. of more than 150bn USD) and the option of Tesla Inc. being included in the S&P 500 (condition: four consecutive quarters of profitable business), thus shifting some payments to the front end by delivering even cars with faults and deficits to make a meager 104mn USD of Q2 profit.
A good house of cards, about which the short shorts will laugh best in the end, maybe in 2020 already. Anyway, Mr. Musk will be over the mountains with 5bn USD in crypto currency by then, just like Jan Marsalek of Wirecard, his brother in arms.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wirecard#Wirecard_and_the_Financial_Times_controversy I may be wrong, but when things seem too good to be true, they're not true in times.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-tesla-model-y/tesla-slashes-model-y-suv-price-as-pandemic-weighs-on-auto-sector-idUSKCN24C0TY
We'll see if this works in the current Very Strange Circumstances.  Musk has enough money to buy most of these himself; this would give new meaning to "stock buyback."

Lower bound: first half 2020 was 150k, which included C-19 shutdown of Fremont plant; so 300k feels very negative Middle: management said they'd get comfortable above 500k before C-19 issues. Overall car industry sales will be down around 15% in 2020. So if we assume Tesla is affected similarly that's 425k units. But yoy growth in Q2 was only -5%, showing great resilience in demand for Teslas through the crisis. Somewhere between 425 and 500 feels like a good median range. Upper bound: production capacity of 600k unlikely to increase meaningfully within a year and production

https://ir.tesla.com/news-releases/news-release-details/tesla-q2-2020-vehicle-production-deliveries reports 80,050 deliveries in Q2. 
This puts the boundaries for the future quarterly average to 46842,71842, 96842 and 121842. The high delivery numbers despite restrictions due to corona also suggest that the effect of the rising amount of infections will be limited. (Although the growth from Q1 2019 to Q1 2020 was a lot more than from Q2 to Q2 and production numbers were down 10% compared to Q1 2020).

4|20|67|9|0

Around 156k Model 3 and Y for H1 in adverse production conditions. https://www.fool.com/investing/2020/07/02/tesla-deliveries-beat-estimates-on-strong-model-y.aspx Looks like between 300k and 400k for the total CY.

Assuming they can make enough batteries to support these unit builds, I see no reason Q3 & Q4 cannot top 100K each. Demand will only increase as other electrics fall short of expectations. My next Subaru will be a Tesla.

On track to get close to or even exceed 2019 numbers despite Covid-19. (Mr Musk's Twitter antics do not seem to bother the companies fans either..)

Tesla said it produced 82,272 vehicles in the three months ended June 30 including 75,496 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles and only 6,326 of its older, higher priced Model S and Model X vehicles

"Xpeng Starts Customer Deliveries Of Its P7 Long Range Sports Sedan" The so called Tesla Model 3-Killer... "The new Zhaoqing factory has the capability of making up to four different models at the same time and a capacity of 100,000 vehicles per year.
The Xpeng P7 is currently the longest range EV currently made in China, beating the long-range Tesla Model 3 by 24 miles (38 km). The P7 has an NEDC range rating of 706 km which translates to 438 miles, and the long-range Tesla Model 3 is officially rated at 668 km (414 miles)"[...]
"Xpeng partnered with battery supplier CATL to co-develop the P7’s prismatic lithium NCM battery cells. The 81 kWh ultra-thin battery pack is only 110mm (4.33") in height and has an energy density of 170Wh/kg. The P7 is also a very aerodynamic and sleek sedan, with a low drag coefficient 0.236.
The P7 is also the first production car to be powered by NVIDIA's DRIVE Xavier system-on-a-chip, delivering 30 trillion operations per second. That's about 12 times more powerful than the chips in most cars today. Its Xmart OS 2.0 hardware uses Qualcomm’s top-line Snapdragon™ 820A vehicle processor, allowing the P7 to launch with level 3 autonomous driving features."[...]
"Price range RMB 229,900 to 349,900 ($32,462 to $49,404 US) post subsidies" https://insideevs.com/news/431829/xpeng-p7-customer-deliveries-begin-china/ Times may become a little more stormy for Tesla Inc. in China.
Hearing there is anticipation of a better-than-expected 2nd quarter (https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-tsla-q2-delivery-estimate-credit-suisse/).
TSLA may have a reasonable quarter after all. We'll know more next week, for now be optimistic.

I am ok with cannibalizing my first two buckets to better represent my bullishness towards Elon's ambitions and recent expansion.
Someone who had the means and desire to buy a Tesla before, likely still does, regardless of the current global situations.
Update based on @RRG's insightful comment [1]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1065477

Tesla deliveries by Y and Q (sorry for the horrible formatting) DELIVERED NUMBERS
YEAR / Q1 / Q2 / Q3 / Q4 / (TOTAL)
2017 / NIL / NIL / 222 / 1,542 / (1,764)
2018 / 8,182 / 18,449 / 56,065 / 63,359 /	(146,055)
2019 / 50,928 / 77,634 / 79,703 / 92,620 / (300,885)
2020 / 76,266 / NIL / NIL / NIL / (76,266) Tesla deliveries by region (despite its recent performance in China with 11k cars sold in May 2020, the Greater China region accounted for less than 40,000 unit sales last year)
- https://insideevs.com/news/395919/tesla-model-3-deliveries-region/ Lets try and build some scenarios and see how the 2020 total gets affected (by varying QoQ growth)
Scenario A - 50% down in Q2, 20% down in Q3, 10% up in Q4 - Total Sales of 281k
Scenario B - 60% down in Q2, 30% down in Q3, 10% down in Q4 - Total Sales of 246k
Scenario C - 50% down in Q2, 10% down in Q3, 30% up in Q4 - Total Sales of 307k
Scenario D - 30% down in Q2, 20% up in Q3, 30% up in Q4 - Total Sales of 356k We see that the below 250k bucket seems very low prob (~ 5%) - since scenario B takes a worst case look and still finds annual sales at 246k Similarly, we see that the above 350k bucket(s) seems low prob (~ 15%) - since scenario D takes a best(ish) case look and still finds annual sales at 355k.  So we will end up in the 250k - 300k and 300k - 350k bucket 80%.  I am going to allocate 50% to the 300k - 350k bucket and 30% to the 250k - 300k bucket because
- Tesla base growth rates, and its increasing presence in China
- Situation inelastic nature of Tesla purchases and the fact that that the market is under penetrated
- Tesla customers would be (relatively) lesser affected by the pandemic So ending up with baseline nos as Less than 250k - 5%
250k to 300k - 30%
300k to 350k - 50%
350k to 400k - 12%
More than 400k - 3%
I'll move to the more conservative position, given the teething issues with Model Y deliveries that are being reported.

"Tesla has some major Model Y quality issues" https://electrek.co/2020/06/16/tesla-model-y-quality-issues/ "The forums are flooded with new buyers reporting issues with their new Model Y, refusing deliveries, and in some cases, Tesla proactively canceling deliveries due to issues. Tesla is currently in its usual end-of-the-quarter delivery push to try to boost its numbers by the end of the financial quarter, but it is accentuated this time by the fact that Tesla didn’t produce any vehicles at Fremont factory for a whole month. Several new Model Y buyers have told Electrek that Tesla reached out to them to schedule a delivery by the end of June only to be told that it had to be delayed because the vehicles had defects."

The ramp rate of the model 3 in both Shanghai and Fremont has accelerated considerably, giving Tesla a combined run-rate of at least 8,000 vehicles a week. Model Y is on-top of this amount and should ramp to several thousand vehicles per week by 4Q.
I’m counting on demand for Teslas being less dependent on the overall economy than demand for other vehicles, and any manufacturing slowdown in Q2 being made up later in the year.
As the world (and China) economy opens again, the demand for it would be high, although it might be dampened by another round of COVID scare and low price of oil.

Reasons 
1. Unemployment above 20%
2. Even multiplying Q1 sales by 4. Its still bare over 250,000 And Q2 numbers will be close to zero
3. The few luxury car buying looking to buy a new car are going to conservative (tried and tested models) especially with gas prices at record lows.
Demand for Tesla's vehicles is not that strong - especially in 2020 with a pandemic going on.
Even during the COVID19 pandemic Tesla has outperformed analysts predictions. As more country’s start opening up sales will trend upward, possibly exceeding 500,000.

Firstly, 2020 is a bad year! The competition is flexing their muscles! Europe and China is where the growth is happening right now! Tesla is American (negative under Trump)! Tesla is technologically superior, but their car making skills is not up to VW, Audi, MB, Kia and Hyundai standards!....yet! Range and acceleration is important, but not everywhere!
Considerations include a few analyst reports, Q1 numbers, 2019 quarterly trends from 2019, impact of COVID closure, overall car markets sales and forecasts.

Tesla has been delivering ca 80-100k cars per quarter, making it likely they will be between 350-400k. This number may be high if Chinese sales are elevated. The effect of Covid on sales increases uncertainty

They sold 60,000 in March 2020 and 15,000 in April 2020. Oil prices will stay low so there will be less imperative to buy one. That being said, they will increase sales from April's low but not to the March levels.
Issues with the production of the Model Y [1]. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-08/musk-says-solving-tesla-model-y-production-issues-top-priority

Tesla expected at the beginning of the year 500k+ units sold, which means at least 450k model 3 and Y given the share of wallet. From there, the covid effect on April-June could reduce the number, but given the progression of sales during the year (seasonality) the bigger part is still to come and should not be affected by covid. China sales were estimated at 90k using Europe's 2019 pattern which looks surprisingly similar, which we added to a simple regression line on past sales providing around 300k units in US - prior to covid. In essence, a point forecast would be around 380k units. Aknowledging for possible large variations (mostly lead by production capacity), we give equal chance within 350-400 than outside of that interval, with great favor of near-achieving the year plan.

Despite having to deal with restrictions around the pandemic, Tesla still had a strong Q1.  Capacity is improving across the Fremont and Shanghai factories and will most likely sit around 700k by mid 2020.

Q1-76,266 [done]
Q2-40,000 (est) [Fremont, CA factory shutdown will hurt the quarter.]
Q3-85,000 (est)
Q4-100,000 (est)
2020 total = ~301,000

Model 3/Y---------------------- Q1/19 Q2/19 Q3/19 Q4/19 Q1/20 Q2/20 Q3/20 Q4/20
Tesla Production----------- 62,975 72,531 79,837 86,958 87,282
Tesla Deliveries -------------50,928 81,956 86,201 98,661 80,430
I'll assume a goal of >100K per quarter with Model Y production now starting in Shanghai.

However, model 3 deliveries were  92,620 in Q4 2019, 79,703 in Q3 2019, 77634 in Q2 and 50928 in Q1 and it seems like there are usually more deliveries in the second half of the year https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-q1-2019-production-and-delivery-numbers-2019-4?r=DE&IR=T
On the other hand, it seems likely that the supply chain was severely disrupted for multiple months, due to Corona. Then again, Tesla claims that they built up inventory at the end of Q1, as they weren't able to deliver as fast any more, so it seems like they kept up production initially. Lastly, it is unclear whether demand will catch up, given the general state of the economy.  Naive extrapolation: of Q1: 76,266*4=305064 
Last year total: 300885
Increase Q1 2019 to Q1 2020:  49%
Upper bound assuming at most 100000 sales per month: around 375000
On the other hand, it seems at least plausible that sales will drop below 50k for one more quarters, which leaves us with a lower bound around 225000. Boundaries in average quarterly sales: 
58000,74578,91244,107911
Forecast (already taking into account crowd of 13|33|33|17|4): 20|39|33|7|1

The question asks for 'deliveries', and although production has picked up in China and Fremont, it is unclear how effective processes at the GFs are after such a friction, if there's a need for hiring or training staff etc. So even if there were "promised/scheduled deliveries" in Q2 which are expected higher than factual deliveries in Q1, maybe at or around 90k 3s and Ys, SARS-CoV-2 will have prevented more than half deliveries from happening in Q2 until now, and I expect the production sites to be packed with 50k new cars. For sure, deliveries will catch up at some time in Q3.
I wonder how the massive government subsidies in a lot of markets will impact orders (in Q3 and Q4) and then, with a time lag, deliveries (in Q4).
So my best guess is:
[Q1 2020: 76,266]
Q2 2020: 37,800
Q3 2020:  131,000
Q4 2020: 98,000
(equals ~ 343,000 deliveries in 2020) I expect there will be rumors in the market from Q3 about a new model and its specs, so demand for models 3 and Y maybe dip in Sept (even with still lowered prices), and deliveries will follow to dip in Q4. In the current environment with health and social issues, I am not expecting any upside surprise, so I rather put my crumbs in the 1st and 2nd basket for more downside risks.

I'll assume a goal of >100K per quarter with Model Y production now starting in Shanghai.
corona has this up in the air
